Rossiiskii flot popolnitsia rezervami Smennye ekipazhi obespechat boevym nadvodnym korabliam nepreryvnoe prisutstvie v dal'nei morskoi zone <<Pervyi obespechivaet dostup Rossii v severnuiu chast' Atlanticheskogo regiona, vtoroi -- v Sredizemnomor'e>>, -- privodit ego slova <<RIA Novosti>>. Kak otmechaet agentstvo, rossiiskie podvodniki stali gorazdo chashche vykhodit' v moria i okeany na boevoe dezhurstvo i razlichnye ucheniia. Tak, v 2017 godu ekipazhi naplavali vdvoe bol'she, chem v 2015-2016 godakh. K tomu zhe v etom godu podvodnyi flot primet uchastie v 500 voennykh manevrakh. Krome togo, RF sozdaet okeanskuiu mnogotselevuiu sistemu, vkliuchaiushchuiu atomnye podlodki, osnashchennye samokhodnymi apparatami s iadernoi energeticheskoi ustanovkoi. Eti submariny sposobny na glubinakh bolee kilometra na ogromnoi skorosti skrytno vydvigat'sia k tseli porazheniia na mezhkontinental'nuiu dal'nost'. 2 maia ukrainskie SMI soobshchili, chto gruppa voennykh korablei NATO voshla v Chernoe more. V sostav soedineniia voshli fregaty ispanskikh, britanskikh, turetskikh i nemetskikh VMS. ChITAITE TAKZhE Bol'shoi desantnyi korabl' <<Minsk>> vernulsia v Baltiisk posle pokhoda Chernomorskii flot vooruzhat korablem s <<Kalibrami>> Podelit'sia: Podpishites' i poluchaite novosti pervymi VKontakte Pochta Iandeks.Dzen A takzhe chitaite <<Izvestiia>> v Iandeks Novostiakh Priamoi efir Novosti smi2.ru Novosti smi2.ru Novosti mirtesen.ru Meniu Podpiska na gazetu Podpiska na novosti RSS Prislat' novost' O kompanii Redaktsiia Reklama Novosti o nas Pol'zovatel'skoesoglashenie Avtorskoe pravo na sistemu vizualizatsii soderzhimogo portala iz.ru, a takzhe na iskhodnye dannye, vkliuchaia teksty, fotografii, audio- i videomaterialy, graficheskie izobrazheniia, inye proizvedeniia i tovarnye znaki prinadlezhit OOO <<MITs <<Izvestiia>>. Ukazannaia informatsiia okhraniaetsia v sootvetstvii s zakonodatel'stvom RF i mezhdunarodnymi soglasheniiami. Chastichnoe tsitirovanie vozmozhno tol'ko pri uslovii giperssylki na iz.ru. AO <<AB <<ROSSIIa>> -- partner rubriki <<Ekonomika>> Otvetstvennost' za soderzhanie liubykh reklamnykh materialov, razmeshchennykh na portale, neset reklamodatel'. Novosti, analitika, prognozy i drugie materialy, predstavlennye na dannom saite, ne iavliaiutsia ofertoi ili rekomendatsiei k pokupke ili prodazhe kakikh-libo aktivov. Zaregistrirovano Federal'noi sluzhboi po nadzoru v sfere sviazi, informatsionnykh tekhnologii i massovykh kommunikatsii. Photo by Alexey Druzhinin/AFP/Getty Images. Russia continues to exert huge influence over both external and internal policy issues - not just in the Russian Federation, but in the the region's newly independent states, and right across Europe.It remains a major global force and Chatham House research and analysis reflects both the country's interests in the region and the high level of influence it carries on the world stage. Torzhestvennaia tseremoniia s pod'emom Andreevskogo flaga proshla v Sevastopole, rasskazal ofitsial'nyi predstavitel' flota kapitan 1-go ranga Viacheslav Trukhachev. Moriaki zashchitiat chempionat mira Chernomorskii flot budet okhraniat' Sochi ot vozmozhnykh terroristicheskikh atak s poberezh'ia v dni ChM-2018 <<Andreevskii flag novogo korablia byl osviashchen v khrame Arkhistratiga Mikhaila, posle chego morem dostavlen k prichalu Minnaia stenka>>, -- privodit ego slova TASS.On dobavil, chto v tseremonii pod'ema znameni uchastvovali, v chastnosti predstaviteli glavnogo komandovaniia VMF, Chernomorskogo flota i vlasti Sevastopolia.Malyi raketnyi korabl' <<Vyshnii Volochek>> predstavliaet iz sebia mnogotselevoi boevoi korabl', osnashchennyi sovremennymi obraztsami artilleriiskogo, raketnogo, protivodiversionnogo, zenitnogo i radiotekhnicheskogo vooruzheniia.On iavliaetsia shestym po schetu korablem modernizirovannoi serii <<Buian-M>> i stanet poka edinstvennym korablem etogo klassa v sostave Chernomorskogo flota.14 maia Chernomorskii flot Rossii otprazdnoval 235-letie. Photo by Getty Images. Europe faces multiple security challenges, as Russia shows its willingness to violate other countries' sovereignty and increase its nuclear power, while the Middle East and North Africa remain in turmoil, and cyber and information warfare are on the rise.In addition, Europe can no longer rely wholeheartedly on US security guarantees, meaning it must have the capability to protect European interests with European troops, including, when necessary, through interventions.This new level of capability requires investment, especially in new technologies, but also greater advancement of pooling and sharing equipment between countries. (0) >> Obshcheotraslevaia informatsiia Aviastroenie Kosmicheskaia tekhnika Raketnaia tekhnika i artilleriia Avtomobilestroenie Sukhoputnaia tekhnika Sudostroenie Radioelektronika Atomnaia promyshlennost' Boepripasy i spetskhimiia PRO Nanoindustriia Strelkovoe vooruzhenie Spets. i zashchitnye sredstva Energetika Metallurgiia >> >> >> >> >> >> 2018 >> Mai >> 14 >> Fregat "Admiral Makarov" pribudet na Chernomorskii flot v tret'em kvartale. 07:13 Fregat "Admiral Makarov" pribudet na Chernomorskii flot v tret'em kvartale. Po slovam glavnokomanduiushchego VMF Rossii admirala Vladimira Koroleva, v blizhaishee vremia Chernomorskii flot popolniat korabli printsipial'no novogo klassa Noveishii fregat proekta 11356 "Admiral Makarov" pribudet k postoiannomu mestu dislokatsii na Chernomorskii flot v tret'em kvartale tekushchego goda. Ob etom govoritsia v pozdravitel'noi telegramme glavnokomanduiushchego VMF Rossii admirala Vladimira Koroleva v sviazi s 235-letiem so dnia sozdaniia Chernomorskogo flota. "Planiruetsia, chto v tret'em kvartale tekushchego goda k postoiannomu mestu dislokatsii na Chernomorskii flot pribudet eshche odin, tretii noveishii fregat proekta 11356 "Admiral Makarov". V blizhaishee vremia budet osushchestvliat'sia popolnenie Chernomorskogo flota korabliami printsipial'no novogo klassa", - skazal Korolev. Po ego slovam, k nim otnosiatsia patrul'nye korabli 22160 tipa "Vasilii Bykov". Takzhe Chernomorskii flot poluchit v svoi sostav seriiu malykh raketnykh korablei proekta 21631, osnashchennykh vysokotochnym oruzhiem. "Poetapnoe obnovlenie vsekh sostavliaiushchikh Chernomorskogo flota budet osushchestvliat'sia kak v blizhnesrochnoi, tak i v dolgosrochnoi perspektive", - otmetil Korolev. Fregat "Admiral Makarov" proekta 11356 (razrabotka AO "Severnoe proektno-konstruktorskoe biuro") zalozhili na PSZ "Iantar'" 29 fevralia 2012 goda, spustili na vodu 2 sentiabria 2015 goda. Pervye dva korablia serii - "Admiral Grigorovich" i "Admiral Essen" - sdali v 2016 godu, oni nakhodiatsia v boevom sostave Chernomorskogo flota. Oni uchastvovali v udarakh krylatymi raketami "Kalibr-NK" po tseliam "Islamskogo gosudarstva" (zapreshcheno v RF kak terroristicheskaia organizatsiia) v Sirii. Korabli proekta 11356 prednaznacheny dlia protivodeistviia nadvodnym korabliam i podvodnym lodkam, otrazheniia atak sredstv vozdushnogo napadeniia kak samostoiatel'no, tak i v sostave soedinenii. Fregaty osnashcheny raketnym kompleksom "Kalibr-NK", zenitnym raketnym kompleksom "Shtil'-1" i raketno-artilleriiskim kompleksom "Palash", artustanovkoi A-190 kalibra 100 mm, torpednym i protivolodochnym vooruzheniem. Krome togo, kazhdyi korabl' neset vertolet. Fregaty imeiut vodoizmeshchenie okolo 4 tys. t, dlinu 125 m, skorost' - do 30 uzlov. Storozhevoi fregat proekta 11356 "Admiral Makarov" na zavode "Iantar'". Popular tags: Europe EU Russia US Germany France Ukraine Popular tags: Europe EU Russia US Germany Popular tags: Europe EU Russia Home GLOBAL EUROPE Africa Americas Asia-Pacific Blogs Contributors About us Contact Us GREEN & SOCIAL EUROPE SECURITY & DEFENSE EUROPE'S NEIGHBORHOOD INSTITUTIONS & POLICY-MAKING ECONOMY & TRADE THINK-TANK EURO-MAGHREB AGENDA Home THINK-TANK In Search of NATO's New Strategies: How to Counter Russia in the Arctic and the Black Sea In Search of NATO's New Strategies: How to Counter Russia in the Arctic and the Black Sea Written by @Eubulletin | Tuesday, July 17th, 2018 @Eubulletin Tuesday, July 17th, 2018 0 0 The NATO summit in Brussels on 11-12 July is likely to be highly political. The Atlantic alliance is increasingly polarized due to disagreements over burden-sharing arrangements, national contributions and transatlantic solidarity, but NATO members cannot let these disagreements get in the way of addressing the 'Russian challenge' - the increasing tensions as Kremlin explores the boundaries of escalation with the alliance while trying to destabilize it. Prospects for improving relations with Moscow are minimal, especially in light of recent developments. The latest meeting of the NATO-Russia Council on 31 May - the first since October 2017 - and the meeting between the chief of staff of the Russian armed forces and the chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff on 8 June achieved very little. Since 2014, the alliance has adapted to focus on Russia's actions in Eastern Europe, notably in the Baltic region and in Poland. But strengthening NATO's eastern flank is not enough. Little has been done to work out a coherent vision for how to protect NATO interests in the Arctic or in the Black Sea. This is worrying since Russia is emboldened in both regions, as seen through brinksmanship such as provocative air maneuvering, an assertive force posture and constant military drilling. In the Arctic and the High North, Russia has been increasing its military footprint there since 2014, through force and equipment deployment - notably by reopening military bases in northern Siberia and Novaya Zemlya, and on Franz-Josef Land - and more drills and patrols, including submarine activities. This has implications for trade routes and lines of communication between the Arctic and the North Atlantic. On the other hand, we have the Black Sea, where Moscow has been militarizing Crimea since its annexation in 2014 and the peninsula has been transformed into a military fortress. Kremlin is also counting on disunity between NATO members which border the Black Sea, especially Turkey and Bulgaria. Both are playing an ambiguous game with Russia and their disagreements are an obstacle to strengthening NATO's Black Sea presence. The most recent NATO deployment in October 2017 - a 4,000-strong multinational land, air and sea brigade-sized force based in Romania - has increased NATO's presence on the Black Sea, though, by contrast, NATO lacks any comparable strategy for the High North. As NATO does not have a clear, united strategy for the Arctic or the Black Sea, both regions will face heightened risks as the Kremlin further builds up its military capabilities there. NATO members should place the Arctic and the Black Sea high on the agenda and develop forces and capabilities to foster greater military mobility and situational awareness, including air policing missions, air and sea patrols and reconnaissance, anti-submarine warfare activities, air defense capabilities and coastal defense systems. For the Arctic, NATO needs to create a special Arctic task force either within NATO's North Atlantic Council or as a stand-alone while it should also include non-NATO partners Finland and Sweden as well as relevant multilateral stakeholders such as the EU and the Arctic Council. Low tension in the Arctic region should remain a priority, while for the Black Sea, NATO should develop a stronger naval presence with Romania as a spearhead and attempt to get compliance from Turkey and Bulgaria. 'NATO Needs a Strategy for Countering Russia in the Arctic and the Black Sea' - Commentary by Mathieu Boulegue - Chatham House / The Royal Institute of International Affairs. 01:39 18 noiabria Voennoe obozrenie Voiti Registratsiia Glavnaia Novosti Mneniia Analitika Vooruzhenie Istoriia Foto i video Novoe na saite Glavnaia Reklama na saite Kontakty Ob izdanii Pravila RSS Forum Voprosy i otvety Nachat' poisk Voennoe obozrenieNovosti Novosti Na storozhevom korable <<Admiral Makarov>> podniat Andreevskii flag 27 dekabria 2017 17 V Kaliningrade na Pribaltiiskom sudostroitel'nom zavode (PSZ) <<Iantar'>> proshla torzhestvennaia tseremoniia pod'ema Voenno-morskogo flaga Rossii na storozhevom korable <<Admiral Makarov>>, soobshchil nachal'nik otdela informatsionnogo obespecheniia Baltiiskogo regiona, kapitan 1 ranga Roman Martov V meropriiatii priniali uchastie komanduiushchii Baltiiskim flotom vitse-admiral Aleksandr Nosatov, nachal'nik upravleniia korablestroeniia VMF RF kontr-admiral Vladimir Triapichnikov, predstaviteli Ob'edinennoi sudostroitel'noi korporatsii, kuda vkhodit PSZ <<Iantar'>>, kaliningradskie korabely - govoritsia v soobshchenii. V torzhestvennoi obstanovke byl zachitan prikaz glavnokomanduiushchego VMF admirala Vladimira Koroliova, soglasno kotoromu SKR vkliuchen v sostav soedineniia nadvodnykh korablei Chernomorskogo flota s bazirovaniem v gorode Sevastopol'. Posle chego ritual pervogo pod'ema Andreevskogo flaga proizvel komandir storozhevogo korablia kapitan 2 ranga Grigorii Breev.Pod'emu Andreevskogo flaga predshestvovalo uspeshnoe provedenie zavodskikh khodovykh i gosudarstvennykh ispytanii, kotorye prokhodili v morskikh poligonakh Baltiiskogo i Severnogo flotov. V chastnosti, ekipazh korablia i predstaviteli zavoda-izgotovitelia v Baltiiskom i Barentsevom moriakh proveli manevrennye i skorostnye ispytaniia korablia, proverili rabotu vsekh agregatov, sistem i uzlov, navigatsionnykh i radiotekhnicheskikh sredstv, a takzhe vooruzheniia korablia. Byli vypolneny desiatki raketnykh, zenitno-raketnykh, artilleriiskikh i torpednykh strel'b.V ikh chisle - raketnye strel'by iz kompleksov <<Kalibr-NK>> i <<Shtil'>>, artilleriiskikh ustanovok A-190 i AK-630, reaktivno-bombovykh ustanovok RBU-6000, a takzhe torpednogo oruzhiia.Ekipazhem korablia vo vzaimodeistvii s liotchikami vertoliotov Ka-27 morskoi aviatsii Baltiiskogo flota otrabotany protivolodochnye zadachi i zadachi poiskovo-spasatel'nogo obespecheniia, soversheno bolee 50 posadok korabel'nykh vertoliotov na palubu storozhevogo korablia.V khode ispytanii korablem bylo proideno svyshe 20 tysiach mil'. We do it by mobilizing conservative activists across the country to make their voices heard. We also hold lawmakers accountable by telling the voters about their records so they can decided whether to support them in the future. ELECTING THE RIGHT CANDIDATES SCA also supports strong conservative candidates by running independent advertisements on TV, radio, and the Internet to support their campaigns. We put principle ahead of party and we aren't afraid to support candidates who challenge Republican incumbents that have lost their way. The Next Great War: Conflict Between Russia and the United States Seems Inevitable Philip Jenkins Tuesday 9 January 2018 5:57pm Share Facebook Twitter Whatsapp Mail Google plus Whatsapp Philip Jenkins is Distinguished Professor of History at Baylor University, and Co-Director for the Program on Historical Studies of Religion in the Institute for Studies of Religion. How exactly are we going to respond to the likely prospect of international crisis within the next couple of years, when that crisis stands an excellent chance of evolving into military conflict? How will we respond to the threat of war? How should we? Looking around the world, several obvious threats face the United States, and the amount of attention they receive does not necessarily reflect their objective seriousness. At the height of the power of the Islamic State, I reckoned it about number five in a league table of likely menaces. More serious was, and is, the danger from North Korea, which has the capacity to use nuclear weapons against the U.S., and Iran, which is working toward that goal. Even if they don't deploy nukes, their conventional arsenals could wreak terrible havoc, especially when supplemented by guerrilla warfare and terrorist actions. At the top of the threat table are two nations with nuclear weaponry sufficient not just to harm the United States, but to devastate it utterly - namely, China and Russia. (They would be destroyed in their turn, but that is small compensation). It would be difficult to choose which of those situations poses the greater danger, and rivalries in the South China Sea could make the Pacific Ocean a lethally dangerous place within the next two to three years. All of these threats feature in a fun article by Robert Farley in a recent issue of National Interest . What I want to do here is to discuss a situation that is presently little known or appreciated in the United States, but it may nevertheless be the area where U.S. and Russian forces are most likely to come into direct violent confrontations, with a high potential for nuclear escalation. I am thinking of the Baltic Sea region. r1783734_28223792 Russian military personnel surround a Ukrainian military base on 19 March 2014 in Perevalnoe, Ukraine. (Credit: Dan Kitwood / Getty Images) In 1991, the former Soviet Union broke up in to its fifteen constituent republics. The present regime in Russia, led by Vladimir Putin, deeply regrets this fact, and has vowed to reverse it by active measures. The most significant aspect of this policy occurred in 2014 in the newly independent nation of Ukraine, when pro-Russian forces effectively annexed sizable border territories, including the militarily vital Crimea. The fact that the West remained so quiescent in the face of this aggression sent a powerful message to Putin, assuring him that future moves would be treated just as mildly. Just how the Russians played this situation demands careful study. At no point did a Russian army or navy threaten Ukraine, nor were Russian forces explicitly involved. Rather, activism notionally stemmed from ethnic Russian groups within Ukraine, who demanded to be protected from an oppressive and essentially fascist Ukrainian government. They formed parties, movements and militias, which campaigned for secession. They were supported by mysterious and well-armed paramilitary units, the so called Little Green Men (LGMs). In fact, the whole operation was directed and organized by Russia, operating through front groups, and the LGMs were obviously Russian military forces. But that thin subterfuge gave Russia deniability, so that the West could never accuse them of invasion, and thus threaten military retaliation. Actions on the ground were powerfully supported in cyberspace, by devastating cyber-attacks on Ukraine and by the overwhelming deployment of Internet propaganda and fake news. Combine cyber-warfare, conventional military actions, and paramilitary dirty tricks, and you have what we call hybrid warfare . Get used to the term, you will be hearing it a great deal. All of which brings us directly to the three Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. From 1919 to 1940, all were independent nations, but in 1940 all were subsumed into the Soviet Union. The Nazis conquered them, but the Soviets took them back and reintegrated them into the USSR. During the process, the Baltic peoples fought a vast and prolonged anti-Communist guerrilla war that lasted into the mid-1950s, a heroic struggle that remains all but unknown in the West: "Proportionally, the partisan movement in the post-war Baltic states was of a similar size as the Viet Cong movement in South Vietnam." Tens of thousands perished. The Soviets then regained their power, and the Baltic Republics shared the ups and downs of the post-Stalin USSR, During that time, the republics were (by Soviet standards) relatively prosperous and Westernized, and they never lost their national identity. In 1991, all three resumed their independence. Crucially for the present argument, they entered wholesale into Western and European identities. All joined NATO, which means that NATO allies have an obligation to defend them if they are attacked or invaded. They joined the European Union, and accepted the Euro currency, aligning them with the core nations moving towards full European union. To that extent, they are as European as Italy or the Netherlands. r1783736_28247794 Map of Baltic Sea area. (Credit: Bergserg / Getty Images) It might be useful here to give a sense of the scale of territory we are talking about. If you look at a map of the Baltic sea, you will see the three nations I have mentioned, and also to their west, a small patch of land (to which I shall return shortly), which is the small detached Russian territory of Kaliningrad. Taking the four lands together makes up about 74,000 square miles, roughly the size of Nebraska. About 6.5 million people inhabit these lands. Assume that Vladimir Putin or a likely successor decides to appropriate some or all of the Baltic states, applying the same methods that worked so swimmingly in Ukraine. The potential for such action is extremely encouraging, especially in terms of Russian minorities who can be represented as victims in urgent need of protection. During the Soviet years, many ethnic Russians took up residence in the Baltic lands, and their descendants remain - around one million in all. All three nations thus have sizable Russian minorities: Latvia 26%, Estonia 25% and Lithuania 6%. Some of these populations are heavily concentrated in particular regions close to a Russian frontier, as in the far north east of Estonia, and the eastern portions of Latvia, around the nation's second city of Daugavpils. If I were Vladimir Putin, I would be viewing these regions greedily as the core of a future secessionist and pro-Russian land, whose inhabitants were clamouring for reunion with Mother Russia. The sizable Russian population around the capital of Riga itself poses a special difficulty for Latvia, which would be the obvious target for a Ukraine-style assault. Presumably, we would see the same 2014-style script, of ethnic Russian movements and groups, supported by Little Green Men. We can also more or less write the propaganda surrounding the campaign, which would likely focus on charges of Nazi sympathies among the leadership of the Baltic states. Given the extraordinary technological orientation of nations like Estonia, the Russians might be harder pressed to launch successful cyber-warfare, but they would certainly attempt it. In the non-electronic world, Estonians and other Baltic peoples have formed militias and private armies ready to resist a Soviet occupation, as they did back in the 1940s. r1783738_28247827 Part of the Russian Navy's Black Sea Fleet in Kaliningrad. (Credit: Vitaly Nevar / TASS via Getty Images) What about that mysterious bit of ground called Kaliningrad? It was formerly known as Koenigsberg, best known as the home of Immanuel Kant. When the Baltics seceded in 1991, this area became an oblast, a physical territory belonging to Russia, although separated physically from the nearest Russian soil by some four hundred miles. It thus presently stands between Poland and Lithuania. It matters so enormously because it is the centre of Russia's still potent Baltic Fleet, which has major ice-free ports at Kaliningrad itself, and at Baltiysk. In the event of a secession crisis in the Baltic republics, Russia has excellent means to intervene directly should it so choose, and (more likely) to deny the area to assistance from Western forces. An awful lot has been written in late years of Anti-Access/Area Denial (A2/AD), and the Russians are very good at it. A Russian move against the Baltic republics would pay multiple dividends. Most essentially, it would reassert Putin's most heartfelt goal of restoring the Soviet Union, with himself as unquestioned master, the heir to Stalin. But it would also provide a critical strategic test for the two institutions that most conspicuously stand in the way of Russian expansion, namely NATO and the European Union. If the West failed to respond to such a direct attack on a member of both circles, it would effectively leave Europe detached from the United States, and largely dependent on Russian good will. Always recall the old semi-joke about NATO's chief functions: it is there to keep the Americans in, the Russians out, and the Germans down. The Baltic gambit would defeat two of those goals at a stroke. No less significant, such a move would pose very limited risks for the Russians. If the Baltic secessionists won, it would be wonderful news for the Kremlin. If they lost and were suppressed, well, we Russians had nothing to do with them, and they were a purely internal Latvian or Estonian matter. We deny everything. Low risk, high potential gain. Why not try it? It's a question of when rather than if. r1783739_28247829 Workmen change the lettering on the Parliament building to a sign that reads "Crimean Autonomous Council" on 18 March 2014 in Simferopol, Ukraine. (Credit: Dan Kitwood / Getty Images) The only slight caveat here is that the Ukraine outcome has been somewhat more time-consuming and difficult than Putin first imagined, which might encourage a degree of caution in the Baltic. Where a Baltic move would be irresistible would be if the United States and NATO were totally focused on some other global confrontation - say, with North Korea or Iran. In that case, the world's media would have little attention to spare on the Baltics. For the sake of argument, imagine that a Ukraine-style crisis developed in Latvia, with intensive use of hybrid warfare. What would NATO do? What would Europe do? This situation would be radically different from Ukraine because now we are dealing with a nation bound to Western nations by close formal ties of treaty and law. Ukraine was not. Baltic leaders have said repeatedly that they would regard the appearance of Little Green Men on their territory as demanding the invocation of the NATO Treaty's Article 5, so that other nations (including the United States) would be required to come to their defence. At the same time, one could argue that this was not a genuine Article 5 situation, because Latvia was not facing an actual Russian invasion, but rather an entirely spontaneous and autonomous upsurge by disaffected citizens and minority groups. And who really knows who those Little Green Men might really be? (They are of course Russian soldiers and special forces, but let's say that very quietly, or we might end up having to go to war.) Adding to the pressure on Western nations would be the unspoken Russian nuclear threat. In recent exercises, Russian forces have made dummy nuclear runs against Warsaw and Stockholm, while threatening nuclear attacks on Copenhagen. Last year, the Russians moved nuclear-capable Iskander missiles into the Kaliningrad enclave, within easy reach of multiple EU capitals. Ultimately, then, any decision to resist an effective Russian re-annexation of Latvia - and then the other two republics - would be a matter for policymakers and political leaders within the United States, the only nation with the possible ability to face down the Russians. What happens then, I have no idea. I can already hear the two sides of the debate. Isolationists and Doves: Are you prepared to risk nuclear war for Latvia? For Latvia? Can you find it on a map? It's not our business. We aren't the world's policeman. We have so many problems at home.Interventionists and Hawks: But if you don't stand up to the Russians now, NATO will effectively collapse. Who would trust our word on anything tomorrow? We are facing a re-run of 1939, and this is no time for appeasement.Given current political divisions in the United States, the debate would very soon get to the issue of whether the administration was cooking up a crisis for its own partisan ends, to distract attention from internal discontents. And then there is the debate within Europe itself. After Russia reabsorbs the Baltics, would they turn their attention to restoring the old Warsaw Pact? Poland would likely be next for intimidation. What happens to the European Union? Those debates might rage at an intellectual level. But there is always the possibility that rival ships or aircraft will tangle with each other in the Baltic, with the loss of Russian or American lives. And then the crisis becomes profoundly dangerous. Philip Jenkins is Distinguished Professor of History at Baylor University, and Co-Director for the Program on Historical Studies of Religion in the Institute for Studies of Religion. His most recent books are Crucible of Faith: The Ancient Revolution That Made Our Modern Religious World and The Great and Holy War: How World War I Became a Religious Crusade. Established 1984 HomeCOMMUNITY FORUMRadiation ReportsLinks & Tools Communication Applications Documents Important Links Links to the roots of the United States Contact Contact Publish Advertise AboutSUPPORT HomeCOMMUNITY FORUMRadiation ReportsLinks & Tools Communication Applications Documents Important Links Links to the roots of the United States Contact Contact Publish Advertise AboutSUPPORT China * Russia * United States Beneath the surface, a quiet superpower race for nuclear supremacy 5 months agoby Yingjie Gu and Matt Sussis502 Views Written by Yingjie Gu and Matt Sussis The world's three largest naval powers are all developing the next generation of their nuclear submarine fleets, accelerating the underwater arms race between the United States, China and Russia. For now, at least, analysts say America remains by far the most dominant submarine force, even as its chief rivals work feverishly to overcome the U.S. advantages. Each country appears to have different strategic goals, with the U.S. bent on gaining greater cost and operating efficiencies while the Chinese and Russian are keenly focused on technological advances and achieving greater stealth. As tensions escalated in the South China Sea, these three countries -- which boast the world's largest navies -- are aggressively preparing for any potential undersea or nuclear conflict, as they develop or perfect nuclear ballistic submarines (SSBNs) and attack submarines (SSNs). These nations have engaged in territorial disputes in those waters, and China has increased its submarine-intensive military drills as a show of force. The U.S. has likely been underestimating the number of attack submarines it would need in the Pacific, given the heightened potential for conflict in the region, warned James R. Holmes, professor of strategy at the Naval War College. "You need to divide the number [of total ships] by two, three, or even more to estimate realistically how many ships are available for duty on any given day. The rest are in overhaul, undergoing training, or relaxing after deployment," Holmes said. "So, divide the number of SSNs in the Pacific by three, then look at the map. That's very few boats to manage events in the world's largest body of water." Nearly half of the $106.4 billion of planned Navy shipbuilding between fiscal 2019 and 2023 will go for nuclear ballistic and attack submarines, according to the Navy's long-range construction plan. The spending blueprint calls for $32.9 billion for construction of ten attack submarines and $16.7 billion for a new nuclear ballistic submarine. The attack submarines are armed with various cruise missiles designed to hit closer-range land and sea targets. They are specifically designed to attack and sink other submarines, surface combatants and merchant vessels. Patrulirovanie etogo nespokoinogo regiona porucheno odnomu iz samykh boevykh soedinenii VMF. Na ego schetu uchastie v sekretnoi operatsii na Kube v 60-kh godakh, v prinuzhdenii k miru Gruzii v 2008-m, v siriiskoi kampanii. Po otsenke ekspertov, u etogo voinskogo formirovaniia dostatochnyi potentsial dlia zashchity vazhnykh ob'ektov infrastruktury. Moriaki zashchitiat chempionat mira Chernomorskii flot budet okhraniat' Sochi ot vozmozhnykh terroristicheskikh atak s poberezh'ia v dni ChM-2018 Kak rasskazali <<Izvestiiam>> v komandovanii Chernomorskogo flota (ChF), 41-ia gvardeiskaia brigada raketnykh korablei pristupila k postoiannomu dezhurstvu po okhrane mestorozhdenii gosudarstvennoi kompanii <<Chernomorneftegaz>>. V zashchite gazovykh vyshek uchastvuiut malye protivolodochnye korabli i raketnye katera. Oni nesut kruglosutochnoe dezhurstvo, rotatsiia provoditsia kazhdye dve nedeli.Ranee posle vossoedineniia Kryma s Rossiei v 2014 godu etu zadachu reshala beregovaia okhrana, vkhodiashchaia v sostav pogranvoisk FSB.Kompaniia <<Chernomorneftegaz>> v 2014 godu pereshla pod iurisdiktsiiu RF. Firma razrabatyvaet shest' mestorozhdenii v Chernom more, obespechivaia bespereboinoe snabzhenie prirodnym gazom potrebitelei Kryma. Deiatel'nost' rossiiskikh burovykh ustanovok nedaleko ot zapadnogo poberezh'ia poluostrova razdrazhaet ofitsial'nyi Kiev. Korabli pogranichnoi sluzhby VMS Ukrainy neodnokratno predprinimali popytki vmeshat'sia v protsess dobychi. Poetomu priniato reshenie napravit' voennye korabli RF na okhranu etikh mestorozhdenii.41-ia gvardeiskaia brigada raketnykh korablei -- odno iz stareishikh morskikh soedinenii Rossii s bol'shim opytom uchastiia v boevykh deistviiakh. Ei, konechno, pod silu zadacha prikrytiia burovykh ustanovok v Chernom more, schitaet voennyi istorik Dmitrii Boltenkov.-- V sostav soedineniia vkhodiat bystrokhodnye korabli s moshchnymi sistemami vooruzheniia. Oni stanut optimal'nym instrumentom dlia resheniia etikh spetsificheskikh zadach, -- rasskazal voennyi ekspert. -- Raketnye katera i malye raketnye korabli smogut srochno pribyt' v raion burovykh i ottesnit' narushitelei. Chernomorskii flot vooruzhili korablem s <<Kalibrami>> Brigada imeet bogatuiu istoriiu uchastiia v spetsial'nykh operatsiiakh. V 1962 godu chetyre katera etogo soedineniia byli perebazirovany na Kubu. Tam oni uchastvovali v sekretnoi operatsii <<Anadyr'>>. Rech' shla o skrytnoi dostavke i razmeshchenii na ostrove sovetskogo iadernogo oruzhiia. V avguste 2008 goda 41-ia priniala uchastie v operatsii po prinuzhdeniiu Gruzii k miru. Togda malyi raketnyi korabl' (MRK) <<Mirazh>> potopil kater voenno-morskikh sil Gruzii. Na schetu soedineniia i uchastie v siriiskoi operatsii. V 2016 godu ego silami byl proveden riad puskov krylatykh raket bol'shoi dal'nosti <<Kalibr>> po ob'ektam terroristov.V 1997 godu Chernomorskii flot byl razdelen mezhdu Rossiei i Ukrainoi. Pri etom brigada polnost'iu voshla v sostav Vooruzhennykh sil RF. Seichas ona iavliaetsia chast'iu Krymskoi voenno-morskoi bazy. Na vooruzhenii soedineniia -- neskol'ko tipov boevykh korablei. V tom chisle -- takticheskaia gruppa raketnykh katerov proekta 1241 <<Molniia>>, MRK proekta 1239 na vozdushnoi podushke, MRK proekta 12341 <<Ovod>>. Poslednie skoro poluchat na vooruzhenie sovremennyi raketnyi kompleks <<Uran>>. V blizhaishie gody brigadu zhdet ser'eznoe perevooruzhenie. Na smenu ustarevshim MRK pridut sovremennye, vooruzhennye krylatymi raketami bol'shoi dal'nosti <<Kalibr>>. Create an account Diana Mikhailova (diana_mihailova) wrote, 2018-07-06 08:19:00 Diana Mikhailova diana_mihailova 2018-07-06 08:19:00 Previous Share Next NATO razrabatyvaet strategiiu protivodeistviia Rossii v Arktike i na Chernom more Sammit NATO v Briussele 11-12 iiulia, veroiatno, budet ochen' politizirovan. Severoatlanticheskii al'ians vse bolee poliarizuetsia iz-za raznoglasii po povodu mekhanizmov raspredeleniia finansovoi nagruzki, vznosov stran-chlenov i transatlanticheskoi solidarnosti. No chleny NATO ne mogut pozvolit' etim raznoglasiiam vstat' na puti resheniia <<rossiiskoi problemy>> -- rastushchei napriazhennosti s Moskvoi, poskol'ku Kreml' izuchaet granitsy dopustimogo v eskalatsii s al'iansom i pytaetsia destabilizirovat' ego.Perspektivy uluchsheniia otnoshenii s Moskvoi minimal'ny, osobenno v svete poslednikh sobytii. Po itogam poslednego zasedaniia Soveta Rossiia -- NATO 31 maia (pervoe s oktiabria 2017 goda -- prim. avtora) i vstrechi nachal'nika General'nogo shtaba Vooruzhennykh sil Rossii Valeriia Gerasimova s predsedatelem Ob'edinennogo komiteta nachal'nikov shtabov SShA Dzhozefom Danfordom 8 iiunia bylo dostignuto ochen' nemnogoe. Pri etom nedavnee utverzhdenie plana <<Chetyre po tridtsat'>>, napravlennogo na ukreplenie voisk NATO i povyshenie boegotovnosti, kotoryi iavliaetsia dolgozhdannym dopolneniem k arkhitekture Al'iansa v Evrope, zastavit Kreml' okazyvat' eshche bolee upornoe protivodeistvie.S 2014 goda al'ians adaptirovalsia k tomu, chtoby sosredotochit'sia na deistviiakh Rossii v Vostochnoi Evrope, osobenno v Baltiiskom regione i v Pol'she. Soglasheniia, sdelannye v khode Varshavskogo sammita NATO v 2016 godu, v chastnosti tak nazyvaemye <<3D>>, kasaiushchiesia <<zashchity, sderzhivaniia i dialoga>> (<<defence, deterrence, dialogue>> -- prim. perev.), po-prezhnemu aktual'ny i dolzhny byt' rasshireny.No ukrepleniia vostochnogo flanga NATO nedostatochno. Malo chto bylo sdelano dlia vyrabotki soglasovannogo videniia togo, kak zashchishchat' interesy NATO v Arktike i na Chernom more. Eto vyzyvaet trevogu, poskol'ku Rossiia vse aktivnee deistvuet v oboikh regionakh, chto vidno po takim primeram, kak manevrirovanie letatel'nykh apparatov v provokatsionnoi manere, agressivnaia stepen' boegotovnosti soedinenii i neprekrashchaiushchaiasia voennaia podgotovka.Arktika i Krainii SeverV Arktike i bolee shirokom regione, izvestnom kak Krainii Sever, Rossiia proetsiruet voennuiu moshch', ozhidaia konkurentsii s raspolozhennymi zdes' stranami, a takzhe s Kitaem. Svoiu Arkticheskuiu strategiiu Kreml' ochertil eshche v 2008 godu, a v voenno-morskoi doktrine 2017 goda nazval krainii Sever strategicheski vazhnym regionom.Rossiia narashchivaet tam svoe voennoe prisutstvie s 2014 goda za schet razvertyvaniia sil i tekhniki -- otkrytiia voennykh baz v Severnoi Sibiri, na Novoi Zemle i Zemle Frantsa-Iosifa, a takzhe za schet dopolnitel'nogo kolichestva uchenii i patrulei, v tom chisle aktivnosti podvodnogo flota. Eto vliiaet na torgovye puti i linii kommunikatsii mezhdu Arktikoi i Severnoi Atlantikoi.NATO, naprotiv, ne imeet kakoi-libo sopostavimoi strategii dlia Krainego Severa: v ee strategicheskoi kontseptsii 2010 goda region dazhe ne upominaetsia, a diskussii po Severnoi Atlantike ne vkliuchaiut avtomaticheski obsuzhdeniia problem Krainego Severa. Sozdanie novogo ob'edinennogo komandovaniia sil NATO v Severnoi Atlantike v fevrale etogo goda bez udeleniia dostatochnogo vnimaniia Arktike podtverzhdaet dannuiu tochku zreniia. Krome togo, chasto upuskaetsia iz vidu Farero-Islandskii rubezh (liniia protivolodochnoi oborony NATO v Severnoi Atlantike mezhdu Grenlandiei, Islandiei i Velikobritaniei -- prim. perev.), soediniaiushchii Severnuiu Atlantiku s Arkticheskim regionom.Chernoe moreV Chernom more Moskva militariziruet Krym s momenta ego anneksii v 2014 godu, poluostrov byl preobrazovan v voennuiu krepost'. Rossiia zanimaetsia razvertyvaniem beregovykh sistem protivovozdushnoi oborony, nadvodnykh soedinenii i udarnogo potentsiala aviatsionnogo bazirovaniia. Teper' NATO prikhoditsia imet' delo s nepriiatnym faktom -- chleny Al'iansa Rumyniia i Bolgariia fakticheski imeiut morskie granitsy s Rossiiskoi Federatsiei.Kreml' takzhe rasschityvaet na razobshchennost' mezhdu chlenami NATO, imeiushchimi vykhod k Chernomu moriu, osobenno mezhdu Turtsiei i Bolgariei. Oba vedut s Rossiei neodnoznachnuiu igru, a ikh raznoglasiia iavliaiutsia prepiatstviem dlia ukrepleniia prisutstviia NATO na Chernom more.Samoe poslednee, razvernutoe v oktiabre 2017 goda soedinenie NATO -- baziruiushchaiasia v Rumynii mnogonatsional'naia sukhoputnaia, vozdushnaia i morskaia gruppirovka chislennost'iu v chetyre tysiachi chelovek, sopostavimaia po razmeram s brigadoi -- usililo prisutstvie NATO na Chernom more. No eto ne iavliaetsia podlinnym sredstvom sderzhivaniia.RekomendatsiiTak kak NATO ne imeet chetkoi edinoi strategii dlia Arktiki ili Chernogo moria, oba regiona stolknutsia s povyshennymi riskami po mere dal'neishego narashchivaniia Kremlem svoego voennogo potentsiala. Eti riski vkliuchaiut v sebia ogranichenie svobody dostupa i provedeniia operatsii na etikh spornykh territoriiakh iz-za ukrepleniia Rossiei protivovozdushnoi oborony i vozmozhnostei po naneseniiu uprezhdaiushchego udara.Risk proscheta i takticheskikh oshibok takzhe prisutstvuet. Neprednamerennyi intsident mozhet sprovotsirovat' katastroficheskuiu voennuiu eskalatsiiu mezhdu Moskvoi i Severoatlanticheskim al'iansom.Takim obrazom, v khode briussel'skogo sammita chlenam NATO sleduet:-- Postavit' Arktiku i Chernoe more vo glavu ugla povestki dnia, poskol'ku obstanovka v oblasti bezopasnosti v oboikh raionakh stanovitsia slabym mestom Severoatlanticheskogo al'iansa. Tsel' dolzhna sostoiat' v tom, chtoby pridat' oboim regionam takoi zhe strategicheskii ves, kak i vostochnomu flangu;-- Sistematicheski primeniat' kontseptsiiu <<3D>> po otnosheniiu k Krainemu Severu i Chernomu moriu. Kremliu ne sleduet verit' v tom, chto on imeet tam voennoe prevoskhodstvo, ili chto dostup NATO k etim regionam mozhet byt' osporen;-- Razvivat' sily i sredstva NATO dlia povysheniia voennoi mobil'nosti i osvedomlennosti o situatsii, vkliuchaia missii po okhrane vozdushnogo prostranstva, vozdushnomu i morskomu patrulirovaniiu i razvedke, protivolodochnye sily, sredstva PVO i sistemy beregovoi oborony;-- Obnovit' morskuiu strategiiu NATO 2011 goda v sootvetstvii s poslednimi sobytiiami i s uchetom riska dopushcheniia proschetov.-- Dlia Arktiki sozdat' spetsial'nuiu arkticheskuiu tselevuiu gruppu libo v ramkakh Severoatlanticheskogo Soveta NATO, libo v kachestve samostoiatel'nogo podrazdeleniia. Vkliuchit' v nee ne vkhodiashchikh v NATO partnerov Finliandiiu i Shvetsiiu, a takzhe imeiushchie k etomu otnoshenie razlichnye zainteresovannye storony, takie kak ES i Arkticheskii sovet. Nizkaia napriazhennost' v regione dolzhna ostavat'sia prioritetom;-- V Chernom more narashchivat' bolee ser'eznoe voenno-morskoe prisutstvie s Rumyniei v kachestve glavnoi sily, pytaias' dobit'sia sobliudeniia soiuznicheskikh obiazatel'stv ot Turtsii i Bolgarii. Ikh nositelem stanet stroiashchaiasia na <<Sevmashe>> atomnaia podvodnaia lodka.Kak soobshchaet TASS so ssylkoi na istochnik v oboronno-promyshlennom komplekse, v sostav sistemy <<Poseidon>> vkliuchat neskol'ko skorostnykh glubokovodnykh torped s malogabaritnoi iadernoi energeticheskoi ustanovkoi. Po slovam sobesednika agentstva, budushchaia submarina ne budet iavliat'sia podlodkoi 5-go pokoleniia <<Khaski>>.V nastoiashchee vremia v sostav VMF Rossii vkhodiat tri strategicheskie atomnye podvodnye lodki tipa <<Borei>> (proekt 955) -- <<Iurii Dolgorukii>>, <<Aleksandr Nevskii>> i <<Vladimir Monomakh>> (pervaia -- na Severnom flote, dve ostal'nye -- na Tikhookeanskom). Oni osnashchaiutsia tverdotoplivnymi mezhkontinental'nymi ballisticheskimi raketami <<Bulava>>, kazhdaia submarina sposobna nesti do 16 takikh raket. Eshche piat' atomnykh podlodok tipa <<Borei-A>> na segodniashnii den' nakhodiatsia v stadii stroitel'stva. Poslednii korabl' etoi serii, <<Kniaz' Pozharskii>>, byl zalozhen v dekabre 2016 goda.Pomimo prochego, v sostave rossiiskogo flota imeetsia odna mnogotselevaia podlodka tipa <<Iasen'>> -- <<Severodvinsk>> (Severnyi flot). VMF poluchil ee letom 2014 goda, no do vesny 2016 goda submarina nakhodilas' v opytnoi ekspluatatsii.ChITAITE TAKZhE Ekspert predskazal protivostoianie Vtorogo flota VMS SShA i podlodok RF SMI uznali o trevoge NATO iz-za rastushchei moshchi rossiiskogo flota Podelit'sia: Podpishites' i poluchaite novosti pervymi VKontakte Pochta Iandeks.Dzen A takzhe chitaite <<Izvestiia>> v Iandeks Novostiakh Priamoi efir Novosti smi2.ru Novosti smi2.ru Novosti mirtesen.ru Meniu Podpiska na gazetu Podpiska na novosti RSS Prislat' novost' O kompanii Redaktsiia Reklama Novosti o nas Pol'zovatel'skoesoglashenie Avtorskoe pravo na sistemu vizualizatsii soderzhimogo portala iz.ru, a takzhe na iskhodnye dannye, vkliuchaia teksty, fotografii, audio- i videomaterialy, graficheskie izobrazheniia, inye proizvedeniia i tovarnye znaki prinadlezhit OOO <<MITs <<Izvestiia>>. Ukazannaia informatsiia okhraniaetsia v sootvetstvii s zakonodatel'stvom RF i mezhdunarodnymi soglasheniiami. Chastichnoe tsitirovanie vozmozhno tol'ko pri uslovii giperssylki na iz.ru. Novosti, analitika, prognozy i drugie materialy, predstavlennye na dannom saite, ne iavliaiutsia ofertoi ili rekomendatsiei k pokupke ili prodazhe kakikh-libo aktivov. Zaregistrirovano Federal'noi sluzhboi po nadzoru v sfere sviazi, informatsionnykh tekhnologii i massovykh kommunikatsii. Find out more about our range of membership and subscription options for individuals and organizations Academy About the AcademyFellowshipsThe Academy FellowsContact the AcademyFAQs About Our Mission History Governance Staff and Structure Our Funding Government Relations Annual Reviews Members login Search form Search HomeExpertsExpert Comment NATO Needs a Strategy for Countering Russia in the Arctic and the Black Sea 2 July 2018 It is important that, during the forthcoming Brussels summit, the alliance recognizes the threat Russia poses in these neglected areas. Mathieu Boulegue Research Fellow, Russia and Eurasia Programme @matboulegue LinkedIn 2018-06-28-Makarov.jpg A new Russian frigate, the Admiral Makarov, is prepared for joining Russia's Black Sea fleet. Photo: Getty Images. Share The NATO summit in Brussels on 11-12 July is likely to be highly political. The Atlantic alliance is increasingly polarised due to disagreements over burden-sharing arrangements, national contributions and transatlantic solidarity. But NATO members cannot let these disagreements get in the way of addressing the 'Russian challenge' - the increasing tensions with Moscow as the Kremlin explores the boundaries of escalation with the alliance and tried to destabilize it.Prospects for improving relations with Moscow are minimal, especially in light of recent developments. The latest meeting of the NATO-Russia Council on 31 May (the first since October 2017) and the meeting between the chief of staff of the Russian armed forces, Valery Gerasimov, and the chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, Joseph Dunford, on 8 June achieved very little. Although a welcomed addition to the NATO architecture in Europe, the recent approval of the 'Four Thirties' plan, aimed at strengthening NATO troops and increasing combat-readiness, will further antagonize the Kremlin.Since 2014, the alliance has adapted to focus on Russia's actions in eastern Europe, notably in the Baltic region and in Poland. The agreements made during the NATO Warsaw summit of 2016, notably the '3Ds' of 'defence, deterrence, dialogue', are sound and should be reinforced.But strengthening NATO's eastern flank is not enough. Little has been done to work out a coherent vision for how to protect NATO interests in the Arctic or in the Black Sea. This is worrying since Russia is emboldened in both regions, as seen through brinksmanship such as provocative air manoeuvring, an assertive force posture and constant military drilling.The Arctic and the High NorthIn the Arctic and its broader neighbourhood, known as the High North, Russia is projecting military power and anticipates competition with Arctic countries as well as China. The Kremlin defined its Arctic strategy back in 2008 and named the High North a region of strategic importance in its 2017 naval doctrine.Russia has been increasing its military footprint there since 2014, through force and equipment deployment - reopening military bases in northern Siberia and Novaya Zemlya, and on Franz-Josef Land - and more drills and patrols, including submarine activities. This has implications for trade routes and lines of communication between the Arctic and the North Atlantic.NATO by contrast lacks any comparable strategy for the High North: its 2010 Strategic Concept does not even mention the region and discussions on the North Atlantic do not automatically include the High North. The creation of a new NATO North Atlantic Joint Force Command this February, without a proper Arctic angle, proves this point. Furthermore, the 'GIUK gap' (Greenland, Iceland and the UK), connecting the North Atlantic to the Arctic region, is often overlooked.The Black SeaIn the Black Sea, Moscow has been militarizing Crimea since its annexation in 2014 and the peninsula has been transformed into a military fortress. Russia is deploying air defence coastal systems, surface vessels and strike aviation capabilities. NATO now has to deal with the unpalatable fact that members Romania and Bulgaria share de facto maritime borders with the Russian Federation.The Kremlin is also counting on disunity between NATO members which border the Black Sea, especially Turkey and Bulgaria. Both are playing an ambiguous game with Russia and their disagreements are an obstacle to strengthening NATO's Black Sea presence.The most recent NATO deployment in October 2017 - a 4,000-strong multinational land, air and sea brigade-sized force based in Romania - has increased NATO's presence on the Black Sea but falls short of being a genuine deterrent.RecommendationsAs NATO does not have a clear, united strategy for the Arctic or the Black Sea, both regions will face heightened risks as the Kremlin further builds up its military capabilities. These risks include restricted freedom of access and operation in this contested environment due to Russia's strengthened air defence and interdiction capabilities.The risk of miscalculation and tactical errors is also present. An unintended incident could spark disastrous military escalation between Moscow and the alliance.Therefore, for the Brussels summit, NATO members should:Place the Arctic and the Black Sea high on the agenda, as the security environment in both areas is becoming a weak point for the alliance. The aim should be to give both regions the same strategic weight as the eastern flank.Systematically apply the '3Ds' to the High North and the Black Sea. The Kremlin should not be led to believe that it has military superiority across these regions or that NATO's access can be contested.Develop NATO forces and capabilities to foster greater military mobility and situational awareness, including air policing missions, air and sea patrols and reconnaissance, anti-submarine warfare activities, air defence capabilities and coastal defence systems.Update the 2011 NATO maritime strategy according to recent developments and taking into consideration the risk of miscalculation.For the Arctic, create a special Arctic task force either within NATO's North Atlantic Council or as a stand-alone. Include non-NATO partners Finland and Sweden as well as relevant multilateral stakeholders such as the EU and the Arctic Council. Low tension in the region should remain a priority.For the Black Sea, develop a stronger naval presence with Romania as a spearhead and attempt to get compliance from Turkey and Bulgaria. Find out more about our range of membership and subscription options for individuals and organizations Academy About the AcademyFellowshipsThe Academy FellowsContact the AcademyFAQs About Our Mission History Governance Staff and Structure Our Funding Government Relations Annual Reviews Members login Search form Search HomeResearchTopics North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) After much debate at the end of the Cold War, it is widely accepted that NATO is the premier security organization in Europe, but its overall purpose in a post-cold war world remains contested. 2017-08-15-BelTank.jpg A Belarusian tank participates in the 2017 International Army Games in Russia. Photo: Getty Images. NATO has opened its doors to the east, inviting the Czech Republic, Hungary, and Poland to join while affirming that membership would remain open to all qualified European countries.But its members have yet to agree on what the organization should do in the modern world. Should its primary purpose remain to defend the territory of its members against direct attack? Or should the Atlantic Alliance focus on security and stability, upholding the rule of law? An alternative would be for NATO extend its reach both geographically and functionally. Established 1984 HomeCOMMUNITY FORUMRadiation ReportsLinks & Tools Communication Applications Documents Important Links Links to the roots of the United States Contact Contact Publish Advertise AboutSUPPORT HomeCOMMUNITY FORUMRadiation ReportsLinks & Tools Communication Applications Documents Important Links Links to the roots of the United States Contact Contact Publish Advertise AboutSUPPORT Middle East U.S. Sidelined as Five Powers Set to Give Iran New Assurance 5 months agoby Jonathan Tirone221 Views Written by Jonathan Tirone Top diplomats from world powers will meet on Friday in a bid to defend their landmark nuclear deal with Iran from attack by President Donald Trump. Foreign ministers from China, France, Germany, Russia and the U.K. will convene in Vienna for the first time without the U.S. in order "to ensure the continued implementation" of the accord, which granted Iran a reprieve from sanctions in exchange for limits to its nuclear program, according to a European Union statement on Wednesday. Trump abandoned the deal in May and reimposed sanctions against countries and companies doing business with Iran. "Austria and the European Union are ready to maintain and deepen the framework for cooperation with Iran," Austrian President Alexander Van der Bellen said following a meeting in the Austrian capital with his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Rouhani. U.S. threats to impose secondary sanctions violate the rights of European companies and individuals, Van der Bellen said. Iran, a key oil exporter that also holds the world's second biggest natural gas reserves, has demanded EU countries come up with concrete economic steps to defend the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. The July 2015 accord, which capped Iran's most sensitive nuclear work in return for the lifting of many sanctions, was plunged into crisis by Trump's decision, even as international inspectors continued to verify Rouhani's government was living up to its side of the bargain. The U.S. accuses Iran of violating the accord's spirit through destabilizing activities the Middle East. "We won't leave the JCPOA as long as we can profit from the accord," Rouhani said on Wednesday, standing next to Van der Bellen. The Iranian leader was on the second leg of a two-day tour of Austria and Switzerland, the two neutral countries in the heart of Europe where the nuclear deal was negotiated.
